feed.title: Combined summary - Does anyone still need testnet3?

entry.title: Combined summary - Does anyone still need testnet3?
entry.summary:
Testnet4, a recent development within the Bitcoin testing landscape, has been experiencing frequent short reorganizations (reorgs) due to an exploit where miners drop the mining difficulty to 1 after a 20-minute period without new blocks. This strategy allows these individuals to quickly publish multiple blocks by leveraging the rule that blocks can't be timestamped more than 2 hours into the future. This behavior also results in the median time past (MTP) of testnet4 typically being set in the future, contrasting with the usual scenario where it's set in the past. This issue inadvertently assisted in uncovering several bugs within the system due to the implementation of timewarp attack mitigation rules. A potential countermeasure has been proposed, which involves reorganizing out those low difficulty blocks. However, this solution is currently only a proof-of-concept from a hackathon and is unlikely to be integrated into Bitcoin Core directly. Implementing such a measure would result in even more frequent reorgs for testing purposes.
In the realm of Bitcoin development efforts, the adaptation to these testnet challenges varies. For instance, Bitcoinj, a library for working with Bitcoin, has begun incorporating support for testnet4, although the integration is not yet complete. The forthcoming version 0.18 of Bitcoinj is not expected to be released for at least a year, highlighting a significant development timeline. Meanwhile, testnet3 remains functional and useful for certain developers, serving as a robust environment for testing code under challenging conditions, thus considered by some as beneficial despite its known issues with block storms. Support for both testnets is planned to continue for the foreseeable future. Additionally, the btc-rpc-explorer, a self-hostable block explorer, has not yet added support for testnet4, indicating varied levels of adoption and readiness across different tools and platforms within the Bitcoin developer community.
The introduction of testnet4 was officially proposed in BIP94 and has been supported by Bitcoin Core starting with version 28. This move was partly motivated by the increasingly impractical nature of using testnet3 due to block storms. The network architecture of Bitcoin allows for the continued use of older testnets like testnet3 indefinitely, provided there is willingness among users to maintain node software themselves. Moreover, the concept of a permissionless signet based purely on proof-of-work has been floated as a theoretical alternative, suggesting ongoing discussions about the best ways to support development and testing needs within the Bitcoin ecosystem. As the community contemplates moving away from testnet3, feedback is solicited from users who might require more time to transition, highlighting the importance of community input in guiding development priorities and timelines.
